patient_text:
So we had a family breakfast this morning at school. I get there and I'm even running a little late and my family's not there. Jess had a flat tire. But Ian won an award at school.

I don't know. You misbehave a lot in the beginning of the school year and then - one year in summer camp I won an award and that was one of three major awards, one of them was Best Behavior and I was in the running for that. And they said that I would probably be happier winning the other award. It's a big trophy but I was pretty embarrassed by it. So you just - for four weeks up you beat up other kids for four weeks and then you stop beating them up for another four weeks and you win the award. There was really only one kid and I didn't beat him up, just hit him once or twice. I said don't cross this line.

He crossed it. I was also being encouraged by the counselor.

So, yes. You ask after four weeks you could. Didn't fit in. So, Jess, I gave all of her the opportunity to do all the IRS paperwork and it hasn't been done yet. And I gave her all the information she wanted from me two days ago. And she has a brief that was due last Friday that she's been working on. And I think Monday's the day that the bank releases the funds. [00:02:11]

And I texted her. I said I forgot to ask you about the IRS paperwork. She's like oh I'm still working on my brief. And then she said if you could pick up Ian, I would have more time, a couple more hours. And I told her yesterday that I have a closing today at one. Cutting it kind of close. I'm in Wakefield at 1:00 doing a closing and I get to Plymouth at 2:30 to pick him up. So I said why are you bringing it up again? She's like, what did she say? She says she didn't mean it to be inflammatory. She's just saying she's got more things to do than time. And I replied I had a side to the same problem. And I explained to her that that was two months rent. And I spent another month's rent on the new office and that leaves me three months' rent in the hole. And she replied that she'd try to get the paperwork to her lawyer today. So I guilted her into it. I still think it's too late. I don't know even if they receive the money if they'll return it.

Yes, so I really saw this as an opportunity to either meet and/or get the name of the person I needed to call or e-mail about how do I get back on the closing list. And they wanted people's opinions, that's what the Community Board does is it advises. So this general practice lawyer from, I don't even remember where he's from - or something like that - just started laying into them about opting in and just all this paperwork they got at the beginning. And the CEO answered that they had to do it for most likely for regulatory reasons, but people just started going around the table ripping them. Just - and I was kind of shocked I mean but that's what they wanted to hear. [00:08:03]

I don't know where it came from but I just was like - so that was kind of good. She said she doesn't know if it was a closed list or open list so there's no guarantee. They're interested in my critiques of the bank. This isn't about getting me signed up to do closings. But this is my opportunity to, if I'm going to get closings, this is my shot.

An open list means that they're adding attorneys or they're letting - will let attorneys - if an attorney refers someone to the bank, that attorney can do the closing. But even on a closed list you still can get on. I'm kind of fudging it by saying that I referred business to the Bank. I did but not a whole lot. the Bank had pretty high standards so it wasn't easy to get a loan from them unless you had perfect credit, perfect income, everything worked out right. But I did have some one or two clients who needed a bank and went and talked to a mortgage broker. You mention mortgage broker and they freak out. So I referred them to one of the loan officers there. [00:10:44]

Yes. And so I was a little flustered and it's just another one of these things like I kind of - my days are just so, they're so disjointed and I'm not sure what I should be doing. I get up to the office in Pembroke and I don't have a desk and shit's everywhere and I don't know where stuff is. I feel like I've got more work to do than I really have and, I don't know. Just, I'm just all over the place. I'm being pulled in kind of a lot of different directions at once.

Yes. It always ends the same way. We want to find a way to keep you in your house. You want to find a way for me to keep sending you money is what you want to do. Nothing's getting rectified and I'm probably going to be making money and I'm basically going to be paying Jess's bills. My health insurance in June is going up from $1220 to $1500 and something.

Yes. It's like they're talking about how nobody's health insurance premiums are going out, everything's working out. There's new cost control measures and what not. Then why is mine going up 20 percent? [00:18:12]

It's just ridiculous. When I first started this health insurance, and this was a family plan, it was $600 and something, no deductible. I'm now on a deductible plan and the copays were only $10. That was six years ago. This is unfucking real. I haven't even told Jess about that. It's a mess. Just...

Yes, it's like a band-aid on an open wound. I did ride my bike to Handball last night, though. I was sore getting up this morning.

It was okay. I'm really having problems with my throws. My shoulder was fucked up last year so that's really affected how I throw. I don't know. It's just exercise. Keep me from having a hard time. Lose all this weight I've been put on. I downloaded all my transactions; it was McDonalds, McDonalds, McDonalds, McDonalds, McDonalds. I'm like I eat a lot of fucking McDonalds. No wonder I'm so fat. You don't eat McDonalds; you're thin. You also work out. Probably some good spinning classes, to power yoga.

Pilates?

Have a personal trainer?

Kelly Ripa does. According to her interview in Good Housekeeping.

Yes. Few days a week.

I felt bad like this morning. I'm reading the magazines in your waiting room...

I've got a closing at 1:00; I still don't have my docs. They haven't approved my HUD, they made changes to the HUD; I've got to make those changes and send it to them. You know, it's just nothing's coming easy. Nothing. She told me over an hour ago that I'd have them in 45 minutes. Maybe they've come through. I don't know. Please remove the lender credit; that was my error in applying this. Please resend HUD for approval. Fucking 24 hours later she picks up her mistake and I don't get the docs until she gets her thing. Fuck. At least I didn't have any mistakes. [00:22:11]

Yes, so I have to...

Well they have, again, they haven't - they won't send those to me until they approve the settlement statement, the numbers. So I had to get that HUD approved and then they'll send me a link to the documents, which I have to print out. And I've got to swing by Staples to make copies for the borrower, all within an hour and a half, basically.

Well I print them out in the office, but then I've got to go and make copies for the borrower, because they're going to sign and I'm going to keep those. So it's just - if I'm running too late I'll just tell them at the table I can scan these and e-mail them to you, or I can overnight documents, I don't know. They never make it easy.

Some of them will send the docs knowing that he just needs to make one small change, but I don't know if she's going to do that or not. These banks, they suck. They totally suck. They all suck, they really do. Everyone's gone out of business, there's only a handful of lenders left. That's why if I get these closings, they're probably like the other Bank, much easier, you know what to expect, and you get the docs well in advance of closing.

At least the borrower's at home. So if I'm late I can call him and say hey I'm late. I'm not meeting him, sitting in my office or whatever. They're at home watching Kelly Ripa.

Yes, and her kids, reading habits. I was working for a firm. There were times I'd stress out about it, then I just got to the point where I didn't care anymore so I didn't stress out about being late. But it's hard for me to not stress out about being late because I've got to make up a lie. I can't call up and say hey the lender fucked up and didn't give me the documents until just a moment ago. I'll say oh there were some technical problems and they were late giving me the docs and I'm putting them together now. That's where the - if they were meeting me at the office then it wouldn't be a problem because I don't have to worry about travel time. But I've got to travel. One of the options is to scan all the documents and print them out, instead of trying to go to Staples. That might be - work better. [00:26:15]

I can reprint them out and try and - the thing is they're not all...

I could, but it's not like they just print you - they print to - it's more than just...

Yes. I probably will do that. I've done it like that before. I don't know. Just they suck. Totally suck. Hopefully soccer gets rained out today. We're having a soccer party afterwards. I have a title that's due today that I haven't had a chance to really even start. Probably has to do that tomorrow. Soccer hopefully gets cancelled. I've got a birthday party, a Cinco de Mayo birthday party to go to.

Grown up party. Bar-be-queing, [inaudible at 00:27:27]. Yes, really sketchy place.

Hip, trendy, your neighbors live in a crack house, yes.

I don't know. It's like from outside it's like a nice, triple-decker, condos all fixed up. And then there's a crack house right next to it. It's like trendy bar, barbershop. Money hashing place, trendy bar, seedy chiropractor, fast food Chinese place. You just look inside and you're like I wouldn't eat. There'll be another trendy bar. Really bizarre. And then there's cop cars whizzing by every moment with their sirens on, the occasional gunshot - okay there's no gunshots but... [00:28:42]

A woman I play Handball with. Her name's I'Hara, they call her Harry; I call her Harry. Cinco de Harry.

Yes. Very...

Yes. So I'll eat hotdogs, drink more than I should. [Phone rings] Who do you think that is?

Oh God, I just want to go to sleep. I want to just - and I can't because of the fucking dog, I can't lie in bed. And I mean now getting up early doesn't make a difference. He's already pissed and shit all over the place. I think the vet's coming next week. And this new medication has something to do with it because his poops are looser and they're different and he's peeing differently and... [00:30:08]

[inaudible at 00:30:11] anxiety. He's on some tricyclic antidepressant, Chloromapazine (ph) or something like that, Chloromapazine (ph). I don't know...

I was thinking about start taking some of see what happens - if it helped me. Probably shouldn't do that though.

He seems like much calmer now. When he used to see dogs he'd just, he start going nuts. Now he just whines a little bit and he still gets aggressive with dogs but he's much more calm. But he still - I hear a door slam and he starts shaking and just - and the kids downstairs, the daughter's plaything violin and the mom's helping the daughter practice her violin and the younger kid who has trouble speaking is going mama, mama, mama, mama. And I have no TV so I can't even drown it out. Mama, mama, mama, (humming), mama, mama, mama. And I can't complain about anything because I'm three months behind in rent.

Is there?

I just put the headphones on and listen to music, NPR, some sports talk radio, or white noise. Yes, Jess has a machine for Lucille, which puts her to sleep. That's weird. Oh God. They need more information from me. It ain't getting fucking done today. I don't know why she didn't ask me for this shit all at once. She wants tax returns, insurance policy stuff... [00:32:45]

Yes. Fucking money's gone, fucking forget about it. Take your time; let them levy your accounts again. I mean when am I supposed to fucking do that today? I've got a closing, then fucking soccer practice, then a fucking after-soccer practice game. Tomorrow I've got soccer games, then I've got to do this work thing. Just - the tax returns are at the apartment so I've got to swing by the apartment at some point, get them to the office to scan them or give them to her. It's not getting done today. It's just fucked up. I wonder why the IRS would be asking be asking for the fucking tax returns. They have them. Go into your little computer there and pull them up. They're there.

I'm completely convinced that Tuesday's going to be a complete waste of my time. Because this is just how everything goes. Just...

Yes.

Thanks. Is that what the book says?

Doesn't the law of attraction have something to do with this? Like I'm attracted to negativity so that's why everything's negative in my life?

I'm not really sure about the law, what the law of attraction is but...

Oh God.

What should give me a reason to think that something's going to go right? I mean even if something does go right, something else is going to offset it. I can't have a moment of success or anything without something completely getting in the way of it.

Yes, it's not possible. If it was possible it would've happened by now. But I've been in a rut that literally can circle the Earth five times. It's one big-assed rut.

It just keeps getting deeper and deeper and deeper and harder and harder to pull out of. Do you need to do some research on this one?

Just think positive and positive things will happen.

That's what Jess would say. She would say something like that.

I'm like a dog who sits in the doghouse and there's a cat and the cat just draws a line. And I start running r-r-r-r-rump. And the chain tightens up and I'm boom, right in front of the cat; can't get the cat. And the cat's just sitting there, smoking a cigarette, looking at it's nails, drinking tea... [00:38:24]

You've seen those cartoons.

They don't make them like that any more. I don't know if kids today are going to about these (inaudible) or something. I feel like Wile E. Coyote. Can't catch that damn Roadrunner. How I survived an anvil being dropped on my head, though, I do not know.

I don't know what they are. It's just how it is. All this time she could've fucking asked me for. Oh come on. She's bugging the fuck out of me. Shit, I just don't have time to get things that everybody needs.

Yes. I should go.

I see they're graduating today.

Oh two days of graduations. Why's that?

Oh I see. I see. And the undergrads the next?

Oh. That's nice.

Uh-huh. Uh-huh.

Mm.

Well no I found one.

Yeah right. I'd seen the robes before but I never could identify where they were from. Now I know.

You know the maroon with the-

Yeah right.

Oh I see. I see.

Do they still wear the same-

Uh-huh. Uh-huh.

I always kind of thought the beret things were neat. (Laughs)

(laughing) I don't know. I guess basically I'm a sentimental traditionalist. (Laughs) Or something.

Yeah I think it's really nice. I don't see why anybody would knock graduation or something like that.

I did too.

Yeah yeah. I thought it was really kind of nice myself also. Somebody says, "Oh hell. Who wants to go?" And all this stuff. "Why should you go?" It's because I'm graduating. That's why. (Laughing) After all that work there ought to be some sort of pomp and circumstance. (Laughs)

Really. But I don't know. What did you read in the papers there is a 16 year old valedictorian who got up and said, "That it was like 13 years of babysitting. That's all you ever did for me." [0:02:12.2]

She says, "When we ask about birth control you say that you can't mention it. And we asked about dope and you send us to a policeman. You don't send a doctor."

And she says, "We're not insane. We're not crazy. And we're your children." It was really kind of nice. I thought, "Wow." She really hit the nail on the head. Thirteen years of babysitting.

But at any rate. Graduation is nice. I remember when I graduated from high school it was like I was-you know graduated from high school. And usually the family would have a big party for you or something.

Like my father said, "No. You just got out of high school. It's no big deal." And I was really pissed. Really upset about the whole thing. So my mother said to me, "When you make it out of college. You know, ha ha. We'll just throw a big party. We'll rent a hall. And have a band. And the whole bit." I made it out of college and she never has yet thrown a party. (Laughs) I'm still waiting for the party. But I kind of remembered those things while working through college.

Yeah right. When I get married then the big party will come. I'll end up paying for it. (Chuckles) Because like I was the first one out of college.

Yeah.

Yeah right. Like out of anybody. But at any rate. (Inaudible) I went home to change after work. And it was really funny that I got a call from this guy who I met in Chicago when I was there last summer. And we had sex together, you know. And he was kind of nice. And we went and saw Chicago together.

But it felt kind of good to say it. I just said, "Goodbye." But he would've been a nice person to know in a straight basis. He was a big man in H.E.W. Health, education and welfare. He would've gotten me a nice job I'm sure. (Laughs)

Oh no. No way. But like he would've been a nice person to know. Like-

Yeah right. As straight.

Yeah right. You know one of those people.

Mm-hmm. Really. Like I said he can call from Portland. (Laughs)

So. Then I thought, I was really glad that I did say no. Even because I would've had to say no even if he did come into New York. If he was making a special trip to New York. I thought, "Sh*t." It would be kind of waste of his time. And mine unless he gave me a job. (Laughs) Because he did mention the last time when I saw him Chicago that he could've gotten me some job or something like that. And those are nice jobs to have. (Laughs) [0:06:26.8]

It's civil service.

I don't know what you do. But like all I know is you travel a lot.

Right. Right. He flies to Alaska and flies all over. I could dig it. (Laughs) But that's life. And that other guy called me. This is something else. I don't why. Like just now. All these people-

Yeah they're all showing up. Like wow. That other guy, Thomas Delcroy, he's the guy who had me in-

Yeah right. The gas.

Yeah right. And he called again. And he said-he wanted to know where I was during the storm last Sunday. And I said, "Well I was in bed. And matter of fact I was in bed with a fine young lady." (Chuckling) I said, "If you want to know the truth." He says, "Oh?" And I said, "Yeah." And he says, "Oh I see." And I said, "Yep." And he says something about you don't plan. Something about the two way or something like this. And I said, "Oh no. When I go, I go all the way."

And it was really kind of funny talking to him too. (Laughing) Just saying all this stuff. And I think like he asked-we sat and conversed about nothing. For the rest of the time. He was really-I think he was kind of floored. To tell you the truth.

Right. Right. And he says, "Oh I suppose you'll get married and have children. And all this stuff." And I said, "Yeah." I said, "Oh we'll have to have lunch sometime. Or go out for dinner. Something like that." Sit and talk for awhile. He says, "Yeah." So that was the end of it. It's really weird. It really was weird.

Yeah right. You like haven't heard from these guys in like years or something like this. But it's really kind of grand just to say, "Well, sorry. Goodbye." [0:08:32.5]

No it doesn't. It doesn't even bother me.

Yeah right. Right.

Oh.

Oh. You ripped off of them at any rate.

(laughs)

That's great. (Laughs)

That's right. Really. Hell of a lot easier. That's grand. It's like - Mr. Heiman, who is the art consultant, they had some voting booths out in the hall. They were going to use for senior. We were thinking of ripping off a couple. But-

Yeah right. It's a federal offense or something. They were just cardboard though. But we ultimately ended up going through it legally and calling the man. And he going down to the warehouse and picking up the used voting booths. But uh -

Cardboard. Yeah.

No no no. Not the curtain ones. The cardboard ones. Yeah. But this man-

Right. Mr. Heiman was saying that they put new sod in front of this new high school. I think it was [Desabo] or something like that. Or Dunbar. They put new sod. One morning new sod in front of the high school. The next morning he drives by and there's new sod on the other side of the street in front of all these people's homes. (Laughing) They all had beautiful sod.

Really. I think it was terrific. They never had grass before. They have it now. Courtesy of. [0:10:29.9]

It was nice. It really turned out well. Comparatively. It was kind of hectic. This afternoon at lunchtime the two women, my two team mates, were on tranquilizers so I decided-I never had one before, you know?

So I joined them in a tranquilizer. It was very relaxing. It really was. Like wow. It was like, I just sat there and watched the play. And nothing bothered me. (Laughs) Didn't even get up out of the seat. It was really kind of nice. And they really-I didn't. They just kind of relax you that's all.

Like I don't know what else they're supposed to do.

Yeah right. It was really, really kind of nice. I don't know if I'd make a habit out of it though. Just you know if you have to depend upon tranquilizers things are getting pretty bad. Oh.

A little bit. A little bit. Not too. I went to bed early last night. I called Tanya. She was in kind of a bit**y mood. Kind of a blah mood. And I wasn't.

Yeah right. You just kind of (makes clicking noise). But I don't know. I ended up talking to her but it was kind of like really kind of blah.

Right. Right. Not at least whatever I was looking for. (Laughing) You know?

But because I was feeling kind of good at that point. And then I thought to myself, "Well we all have our bad moments." Including I. So imagine she feels the same way if I'm in rather a lousy mood. [0:12:39.8]

Yeah right. Do anything or you know. So I just thought it happens to everybody. It's getting around to the end of the year. And getting all this stuff together. Something I'm not looking forward to. (Chuckles) You know it's like doing report cards. And doing [cue] cards. And packing and all that stuff.

And just really kind of a pain in the a**. And what do you do with 31 children while you're trying to get all the rest of this stuff done. I wish I could just go home and stay. We tried that once but they all showed up. (Laughs)

Telling them to stay home. (Laughs)

We did. Truthfully. I think it was the last day before Christmas or something. We weren't going to do anything. It's just like it's just going to be getting things together to go on the Christmas break. Just throwing subtle hints like, "Oh I imagine you have some last minute shopping to do. And your mother would like to take you shopping. Don't strain yourself to come." But they all came. (Laughs)

We were practically giving you a written invitation to stay home. Mm. Some of the kids I had in 7th and 8th grade they came back from another school to see the play. God like it's this new person. They've all developed. They've all passed puberty now. [0:14:30.1]

It's just like I didn't even recognize half of them.

Oh wow. Twice as tall as you are. And it's really a weird feeling.

Yeah right before that age. And then-

Uh-huh. They just-oh it was unbelievable. I had this one kid. I didn't even know who he was. I couldn't-And I had him like only two years ago. He was so different. He was so scrawny and little and now he's just so big. It really makes a hell of a difference. It was kind of nice though to see them. They come up and say hello and all this stuff. This one girl though. Shawna she used to give me hell. You know?

But she was nice in her own way. And the teacher had to get her. And I said, "Christ, she hasn't changed." (Chuckles) The other one. Chyna. Oh God. She was really bright. Really bright. And she was bright enough to start trouble and stay out of it. And you know just really clever.

Really a clever girl. But she's, God in 8th grade now and sleeping with guys and carrying on. Unbelievable but she's got more brains. She's supposed to be going on to [Lindbloom]. Which really isn't a bad school. If she makes it. If she doesn't play, she'll be fine.

I mean she's the type that stuff that we were doing in grammar school, pfft.

You know.

What's that the twenty-

22nd. 23rd. Yeah. And have a place to stay and everything? Oh that's nice.

That's nice.

A house? Hey. (Chuckles)

Well. It's better than an apartment.

Uh-huh.

I did too.

(laughing) I remember when my brother and I, we used to let it grow so long. And it just-of course we never had a power mower. (Laughing) It was like the two of us. Mm. You know. Nothing.

Uh-huh. Yeah they are.

Right. If you'd like to take care of them.

Oh yeah. Probably.

(Laughing) Something you can rip off of it. I really can't-I guess a lot of people must enjoy it. It's really - . There was this like the one witch who used to live in the block. So you'd just be more antagonistic towards her. (Chuckles) And then on the other hand there was this one man who used to live in the back. I mean we'd use his yard for a play area. We built a tree house up in his tree. [0:21:19.5]

He used to build little wooden carts for us with the wheels on it and stuff like that. Who was really a nice guy. I don't know if he was a bachelor or something. Lived with his sister. He was an old man. He used to have one of the cars with the running boards. And we used to hop on the running boards.

And during the winter we used to stand by stop signs and hitch the rides in back of the cars. And he'd always let us get on. Of course it was very dangerous. I realize that now. (Laughs) But he was really nice. And buy anything off of you. Whatever you were selling he'd buy it off of you. I always wondered-know what happened. I think he moved to Texas and retired. To Texas. I was wondering if Tanya was pissed about our last conversation. I'll have to ask her.

Yeah right. If she was upset about that.

Yeah right.

Yeah right. And she doesn't say. Like I said to her, "Well what's happening like tonight?" And she says, "Well nothing really." And I said well I had to come here and like I'd be through about 5:30 or so. And I said, "Well do you want me to come by your place?" "Well I don't care."

Yeah right.

Yeah right. And she says, "Well if you'd want to." Or stuff like this.

Yeah. And like I'm saying, "Well whatever you want to do is fine with me. If you want to come this way or you want me to go that way. It really doesn't make that much difference." And she'll never say well I really feel like coming over. And I'd-so fine.

Yeah right. And she said, "No nothing." Just. (Chuckles) It's like no, nothing. And you could really kind of tell there was something bothering her somewhere. And she just kind of (inaudible at 0:23:38.6).

Yeah right. Yeah right. Something. Some yes or no. Or tell me to go to hell. I don't care. Say something. It's just better than nothing. Which really drives me insane. Because you know that when a person is thinking something, and you know a person is thinking something, it really just drives me up a wall. It really does. [0:24:09.1]

"We should only have two because it's getting a little crowded up there." And she was kind of like apprehensive just letting the two go up there.

And I talked to her later and I said, "If I said something that was kind of like offensive or you thought there should've been six or something, why don't you say something? If you would've said something." And she said, "You know me better than that. If had something to say; I'd say it." Which is true. She would. She says, "There were just so many other things on my mind that I just wasn't there. I was just kind of out of it." Which is really kind of nice. And I was really kind of glad that I asked her about it.

Because I was feeling kind of rotten. I thought well did I say something wrong?
